Yes, the same neural mechanisms that allow the brain to process and switch between spoken languages also apply to sign languages. In fact, studies have shown that when people who are bilingual in sign languages switch between languages, the same neural regions that are involved in spoken language switching are activated.

Similarly to spoken languages, sign languages also involve complex cognitive processes, such as syntactic and semantic processing, and contextually dependent interpretation. Bilingualism in sign languages has been linked to cognitive benefits, including improved executive function and cognitive flexibility.

Overall, the brain's ability to process multiple languages and language modalities, including spoken and sign languages, is a remarkable example of the brain's adaptability and plasticity in response to the demands of the environment.
